episode_title: How the $574B Digital Media Industry Is Being Disrupted by a Sesame Street Alum with Caroline Strzalka
transcript:
ï»¿Nik (00:00.96)
All right, Caroline, why don't you give us some of the meat and potatoes? Tell us what your business is and how you make money.


Caroline Strzalka (00:06.519)
Sure. So I'm Caroline Csukka. I am the founder of Overplay. Overplay is a no -code solution for making any video into a game. So the way I like to describe it to people is that we're like TikTok for gaming. So you can download Overplay. It's an app right now for both iOS and Android, and you can download it. And you're just scrolling through mini games that are made from videos that anyone can make and anyone can play.


And these are tapping, swiping, jumping, driving games. basically what you're doing is now you're having an interactive experience with video. And it's awesome. It's like the next, it's what's next for social media. It's what's next for commercials. It's what's next for anyone doing anything in media or video.


Nik (00:55.308)
Could you give me just a quick example of what, let's say I have a video on my phone, what kind of a video would I use to turn into a game?


Caroline Strzalka (01:03.349)
Yeah, so maybe you went to a Taylor Swift concert. You know, you took your kid to a Taylor Swift concert. There's this like really great video of Taylor dancing on the stage. And now you can make her dance into like a swiping game. And so the kind of interaction that you have with this content now is that if you think about Dance Dance Revolution or Guitar Hero, where the goal of those games is to match the action you see on the screen. Now with your thumb, you're having to swipe, swipe, swipe as Taylor's dancing.


And if you're doing it accurately, you're getting points now based on how accurately you're putting in the input and you're getting rewards. so, and then there's a leaderboard at the end and everything too. So now, yeah, you could take literally a video of anything and make it into a game. You know, maybe your dog is running around the park and jumping over logs. And now you can make that into like also maybe a swiping game or a tapping game.


Nik (01:50.126)
That is awesome.


Caroline Strzalka (01:59.861)
or maybe you're recording, maybe you're using your GoPro and you are recording a mountain biking trail that you're going down and you're recording that and now you can make it a POV driving game, you know? So literally anything can now be made into a game and you can do this within minutes.


Nik (02:17.432)
So you have had a really cool run over the last little bit. You obviously started this company. You've raised a couple of different rounds. You're currently raising around on WeFunder. Mark Cuban has invested. You've been on Shark Tank. What was it about this business that attracted you to it? And why do you think it's resonating so well with people?


Caroline Strzalka (02:39.127)
Sure, yeah. It's one of these things where my co -founder, I've known my co -founder for now like 16 years or something like this. We worked together at Sesame Street and his name is Dan Projanski. And one day Dan told me about this idea of how he thinks that he came up with a way to turn any video into a game. And automatically like my business development hat went on and I was like, my God, Dan, if you could build that and we could patent it.


I was like, that is like the goose that laid the golden egg. It's really what we would have wanted at Sesame. you know, coming from the media industry where it costs so much money to film content, it costs a lot to film live action Muppets as you might have thought about or not, but it costs a lot of money. And so we're always trying to create a long tail for that content, you know, trying to...


Can that video be used in an app or can it be used in an ebook or something like this? We're always trying to make that content go further. And to make games is really expensive. Even the easiest game that Sesame was making for apps or whatever, was like $25 ,000 to make that game. Yeah, I mean, it's probably gotten more expensive since then. And so...


Nik (03:57.1)
to make the game.


Caroline Strzalka (04:03.703)
you I was like, my gosh, if video could be used as the asset that you then are putting the layer of gaming on top of that solves so many problems because you're taking the most expensive parts of making a game out, right? You're taking out the asset creation, the engineering that all has to go behind it. And, and yeah, these are snackable games. So these are like 30 to 45 second games. They're like, they're games that you're getting that quick, you know, hit of


Nik (04:13.08)
Yeah.


Caroline Strzalka (04:32.363)
You know, maybe it's just fun or maybe it's educational or whatever it is, but that might just do the trick for what you're making. So these are not AAA title games with, you know, that cost millions of dollars. These are really easy to make games. Yeah.


Nik (04:45.666)
Well, so on top of that, the gaming industry is massive, I mean, it's like it's more than a half a trillion dollar a year industry. Is that right?


Caroline Strzalka (04:49.419)
Yes. Yeah.


Caroline Strzalka (04:54.419)
Yes, and yeah, gaming is like the biggest form of media out there and it's growing exponentially every year. You know, the stats around the amount of people that play games every day, it's like now it's like the majority of Americans and as you go to like Gen Z, it's like, yeah, everyone is playing at least a game. And if you think about games, it's like people are playing casual games, you you're on the subway, you're playing a game, you know, my head of games called them.


call them toilet games, you you're in the bathroom, you're playing a game. We don't like to admit it, you know, but, you know, you're, you're taking the time and then people are also playing the AAA title, you know, games. But it's, it's huge. these are like, you know, 60 hour plus games where you're, you know, completing the multi level. These are, yeah.


Nik (05:32.536)
Yeah. What does that mean, AAA?

Also, so AAA is an actual, I guess not brand, but like category of games.


Caroline Strzalka (05:47.389)
yeah, category of games, right. Like, so this is like Madden, you know, football or, you know, or this is that kind of thing, you know, where you're playing on a console system on Xbox or whatever, you know? Yeah.


Nik (05:59.128)
So what I find interesting is like there's kind of two paths into entrepreneurship. I mean, there's lots of paths into entrepreneurship, but I think there's two differentiators into entrepreneurship. There's the regular sweaty startups, just any business that you could go into and start. And then there are tech startups or venture backed startups. And those are the ones where you have to go out and raise money. The former...


Caroline Strzalka (06:18.689)
Yeah.


Nik (06:23.95)
It may take a year or two for you to get to a place where you're consistently profitable, but you can bootstrap that business. The latter, it may be a 10 year or even 20 year horizon before you're like really seeing the fruits of your labor. I'm curious. This industry is so big. It's you found a way to do it cheaper than most other gaming companies. Why did you decide to raise and why not go the bootstrap route?


Caroline Strzalka (06:40.897)
Yes.


Caroline Strzalka (06:47.979)
Yeah, with this, it's very, very difficult to go the bootstrap route. This is software that we were making something that's never been built before. So we really did need a team of engineers to make both the game maker and the game player. And we built this both for iOS and Android. So this takes a lot of money. This is not one of those things where you can like kind of piecemeal it, release it, charge people money for it. It's just, it's not one of those businesses.

Mm

where you have to kind of go whole hog, hire the engineers. I mean, this automatically costs hundreds of thousands of dollars even to get going. And so,

Mm

So how did you even get to the, cause if you're getting into entrepreneurship and how did you even get the idea, obviously you're working at Sesame Street. How did you get the idea to say, all right, let's, Dan, let's spin this out into a real company.


Caroline Strzalka (07:32.79)
Yeah.

Yeah. So what actually ended up happening is that, you know, we, Dan and I, we kept our day jobs and Dan had this nugget of an idea. whether this could even be built, right? So Dan had this idea of how to now, a brand new way to make games on top of video. And we didn't even know whether it was possible, right? From that, we were able to get the MVP.


share the MVP with a lawyer who was then able to see how big this could be, right? And we're able to get the patent for this, right? So to get the patent. Yeah, yeah.

A lawyer? Why a lawyer? okay. Okay. So sorry. He so he wasn't like telling you, hey, you should go raise money for this. He was saying this is or is not patentable.

No, no, we knew that if this could be built, this is a multi -billion dollar idea. This is worth a lot of money. And when you're thinking that way, you know that you have to go the venture backed route. There is no bank that's going to lend you the millions of dollars that you need for this. Like we are, you know, pre -revenue, we're still pre -revenue. And so there's, this is not a traditionally bankable idea.


Like when you have something, especially in the software space, that's highly scalable and that could be huge. You want to have a billion dollar idea. it, if it check marks those boxes, then you know, you have a venture backable idea. And sometimes with ideas like this, you know, it, can only really go down the venture route because this is like one of those things where they have to believe in the future of what the software could produce in terms of revenue. And banks don't believe in you.

at that stage,

at Sesame and running that whole team. So he's just one of these brilliant guys, but it was film. Mm

You went to University Penn undergrad and Wharton MBA. right.

What year?

you know, they came in, they're rough around the edges. And in a way, being a banker, that seed was already planted in my head that I was like, if these guys could do it, I could do it too. There's nothing stopping me from doing this. I am so yeah, so I went to I went

Thank

to business school, I knew that I didn't want to go back into banking. I already had done my stint there. did not. mean, I the way that you learn about Wall Street is by working on Wall Street. And I was really intrigued by both and Wharton's curriculum in that area. And entrepreneurial management, it kind of gives you like the scaffolding around which you could kind of think about starting a company. The easiest thing to do normally is like start an agency business. Maybe you're a

to not just answer the surface level questions, but the second, third, fourth order questions because they're putting a lot of money and capital behind you. so to hear you like preparing for that and understanding what is needed in those pitches, there's like one skill that's being developed. Then you go over to Sesame Street and you're like, this, this makes sense. Well, before Sesame Street, you develop, you go to get your MBA in marketing and entrepreneurial management.


you go to Sesame Street and you start learning about content, you meet somebody there, and then all these pieces come together where with Overplay, it's a no -brainer to invest in Caroline at this point because it's like, yeah, she has all of these experiences. is to put yourself in challenging situations. And I will tell you, being an investment banker right after undergrad, it's like being thrown in the fire, right? Like it was super challenging, but I knew that I would come out, like if I kept my eyes and ears open, like I'd either come out, you


knowing people that would be useful in the future for me or with an idea or something like that. And then going into Wharton for my MBA, I kind of came in a little bit open knowing that I was like, I don't need to study finance. I've already done that. And let me see what else is out there. And so I was like exploring a variety of classes and I was like, I really, I just had that feeling in the back of my mind that entrepreneurship would be there. And then,


You know, I took the job at Sesame after MBA, which is not normal for a Wharton MBA to go into a nonprofit. and, but it was, it was really interesting cause I kind of, once again, kept my options open. didn't want to go into management consulting, because I actually like making stuff, that actually, like, I felt like management consulting was a lot of like, you know, writing up decks.


for a client that ended up never being implemented. I wanted the work that I did to somehow be useful to the world. I wanted to make stuff. I get lot of pride in being able to make something.
